Dear Mr. Burrows, I am sorry not to have been very quick in replying to your letter of 26th May about the Sultan of Muscat’s rupee investments. This is a rather embarassing enquiry, since it would, I think be quite improper for H.M.G. to warn the Sultan off Indian investments whatever they were like. Fortunately, though it is true that India may have some trying financial times ahead, we feel we can conscientously advise him that we have no reason to think that his Bonds are not safe. We could perhaps add that rupee securities are, in our view, a very appropriate form of investment for the reserves of a country w r hich uses rupee currency. If the Sultan wanted to sell out and transfer the proceeds out of India he would have to get the consent of the Indian authorities. If he wanted to get into sterling we should be prepared, at the request of the Indians, to make a release for the purpose from India’s blocked sterling balances. The position is, in fact, that described in my letters of 8th and 23rd November 1948 to Mr. Stewart about the similar case of Bahrein. We are not particularly anxious that people who hole rupees should switch into sterling at the expense of releases from Indian blocked sterling and I agree with you that there is no need to give the Sheikh any advice on tlie subject unless he asks for it. Yours sincerely, (Sgd•) MABY LCUGHNANE B.a.B. Burrows, Esq., Foreign Office, London.

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file contains a small amount of correspondence concerning the state finances of the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman. The letters discuss the Sultan of Muscat and Oman's [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd] investment in Government of India war bonds, as well as details of the Sultan's accounts with Lloyds Bank and the British Bank of Iran and the Middle East (formerly the Imperial Bank of Iran). Correspondents include the following: the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat; officials of HM Treasury, the Foreign Office, Lloyds Bank, and the British Bank of Iran and the Middle East.
